question: Business liquidating but still has debts
answer:
QUESTION
What is the position of a business going into liquidation known to be owing many people monies, for stock purchased, and perhaps in a month or later opening another business on another name? The previous director/s still live the same lifestyle and drive around in the same luxury cars. By becoming liquidated, are they absolved from paying their debts?
ANSWER

Almighty Allah Ta'ala states in the Noble Qur'aan 'Oh you who believe, Do%0D%0Anot eat your wealth among yourselves unjustly, except that it be a%0D%0Atransaction with mutual happiness.' (Sura Nisaa Aayat 29). %0D%0A%0D%0AThe prohibition %0D%0Aof unjustly eating the wealth of others includes dishonouring a debt. Allah%0D%0ATa'ala and Rasulullah (Sallallaahu Alayhi Wasallam) have announced serious%0D%0Awarnings and punishments for dishonouring debts. Consider the following%0D%0Aquotations.%0D%0A%0D%0A* And whosoever does that (unjustly eats the wealth of others), We will soon%0D%0Aburn him in the fire (Ibid).%0D%0A%0D%0A* Hadhrat Abdullah Ibn Umar (RA) narrates that Rasulullah (Sallallaahu%0D%0AAlayhi Wasallam) said every sin of a Shaheed (martyr) is forgiven but debts.%0D%0A(Mishkaat Pg. 252, Me'raaj).%0D%0A%0D%0A* Hadhrat Abu Hurairah (RA) narrates that Rasulullah (Sallallaahu Alayhi%0D%0AWasallam) said, 'The soul of a believer will be suspended (from entering%0D%0AJannah) due to his debt until paid.' (Ibid).%0D%0A%0D%0A* Hadhrat Abu Hurairah (RA) narrates that when the janaza of a deceased who%0D%0Awas in debts used to be brought to Rasulullah (Sallallaahu Alayhi Wasallam),%0D%0Ahe used to enquire whether the deceased had left moneys in his estate or%0D%0Anot; if there were moneys (to honour the debts) then only would he perform%0D%0Athe janaaza (Ibid).%0D%0A%0D%0A* Hazrat Abu Hurairah (RA) narrates that Rasulullah (Sallallaahu Alayhi%0D%0AWasallam) said, the (undue) delay of a wealthy person in paying his debts is%0D%0Aoppression (Mishkaat Pg. 251, Me'raaj).%0D%0A%0D%0AIn an Islamic State it is the responsibility of the ruler to secure payments%0D%0Aof debts. If a debtor has some wealth, the ruler will imprison him until he%0D%0Asells his belongings - in order to honour his debts. (Raddul Mukhtar vol. 6%0D%0Apg. 150 HM Saeed). If he refuses to sell his belongings, the ruler will then%0D%0Ahimself sell all his belongings and distribute it to the creditors pro-rata%0D%0Atheir debts. The ruler may leave only one set of clothing for the debtor to%0D%0Acover his body (Hidaya vol. 3 - chapter of Hajr). The ruler even has the%0D%0Aright to take all his (debtor's) cash and pay the creditors without the%0D%0Aconsent of the debtor.(Ibid) According to Imaam Abu Hanifa, after the%0D%0Alitigation process of any possible recovery of debts, and the debtor being%0D%0Adeclared insolvent by the ruler, then too the debtor is not absolved from%0D%0Ahis debts. Rasulullah (Sallallaahu Alayhi Wasallam) said that the person%0D%0Awith the right (creditor) has a hand and tongue. (Nasbur - Raayah Zailaee%0D%0Avol. 4 pg. 166 - Majlis - Ilmi). The hand and the tongue in the above hadith%0D%0Arefers to the constant demand of the creditor for the payment of the debt.%0D%0AThe creditors have the right to take the earnings of the insolvent debtor%0D%0Aand divide it among all creditors. (Hidaya Ibid)%0D%0A%0D%0AFrom the aforegoing, it is clear that the rules and principles of insolvency%0D%0Ain the secular system does not corroborate with the laws and principles of%0D%0Ainsolvency in Shariah. It is not permissible to search and create a loophole%0D%0Ain the legal system and declare oneself insolvent in order to avoid payments%0D%0Ato one's creditors. That will be regarded as oppression and a major sin. If%0D%0Athe debtor still owns a house, cars, etc., according to Shariah he is not an%0D%0Ainsolvent person. He should sell his belongings, car, house etc., and honour%0D%0Ahis debts. However, if a person is honestly insolvent, he should seek the%0D%0Aforgiveness of his creditor and make every attempt to pay the debt. He%0D%0Ashould also record the debt in his will. Rasulullah (Sallallaahu Alayhi%0D%0AWasallam) also advised the creditor to be lenient to his debtors. If%0D%0Apossible he should grant respite for late payments or remit the entire or%0D%0Apart of his debt. Rasulullah (Sallallaahu Alayhi Wasallam) informed us of a%0D%0Acreditor being forgiven by Allah Ta'ala for his sins due to his leniency to%0D%0Ahis debtors.%0D%0A%0D%0AAs Muslims we should be conscious of our accountability in the court of%0D%0AAllah Ta'ala and be truthful in all our dealings.%0D%0A%0D%0Aand Allah Ta'ala Knows Best%0D%0A%0D%0AMufti Ebrahim Desai%0D%0A%0D%0A
